^^^ obviously, you didnt listen and havent closed down your Anti Virus and its removed the file!!

Turn off your AV then extract the files again, right click on the .exe file and paste it into your (C:) drive next open up the CMD

Start > All Programs > Accessories > Command Prompt (or just type CMD in the search bar and hit enter)

Then copy and paste this C:\w7lxe.exe /office2010
into the CMD and press enter!!
Job done!! seems simple enough to me!!
Hope this helps!!

I followed the directions from the 'read me' file. It works, (I use Windows 7) but overall it's not the best KMS activator for Office 2010. 

I set the system date to about 6 months ahead from now (to test what will happen after 180 days) and then restarted the computer, hoping this activator would automatically activate itself. I checked the activation status with another KMS activator and MS Word. My Professional Plus was in Out-of-Tolerance Grace and the help menu in Office said: Product Activation Required. So it's not "lifetime" activation if you need to manually reactivate it yourself every 180 days. Some activators (such as Raz0r's Office 2010 Activation and Conversion Kit 1.6 and CODYQX4's Office 2010 Toolkit and EZ-Activator 2.0 Beta 3) automatically reactivate Office when the computer is restarted. Is there a way to have this activator reset itself before the 180 days are over? Thanks for the upload though. I know a few people with unactivated copies of Windows 7 and this seems like it'd work perfect for that.

I think as someone else did, they rolled their computer ahead by 180 days, and that is the limit.

This is indeed a Windows 7 Activator, but it's also working with Microsoft Office 2010.
However, using this activator on XP requires some additional files:

1. pidgenx.dll, which is not a part of XP, can be downloaded and copied to 
C:\Windows\System (Windows 95/98/Me) 
C:\WINNT\System32 (Windows NT/2000)  
C:\Windows\System32 (Windows XP, Vista, 7)

2. advapi32.dll is part of XP, but it gives an error (when pidgenx.dll is already copied to the 
system folder):"Cannot find the enrtypoint procedure RegDeleteTreeW in a DLL-file of advapi32.dll".
The advapi32.dll from Windows is a newer version than the advapi32.dll which can be downloaded.
Also advapi32.dll is a running XP system file, and stopping and replacing it with the older 
advapi32.dll may cause problems. 


To me it's not worth taking the risk replacing the original XP advapi32.dll with the older one,
so I can't tell if this works on XP, and so far no one confirmed.

Bottom line: To avoid complaints maybe the uploader should mention the problems when using this 
on XP, once the edit feature is fixed.

Great upload, thanks.  The so called trojan everyone is worried about is a file placed in the temp folder that tries to access the web, but Windows Firewall blocks it.  If you let it through it activates the product.  After activation you can just empty your temp folder if you're worried about it.  The other link someone posted that's supposed to be the same thing without this "trojan" does the exact same thing when ran from the command line like this one and it too gives a false positive.  People should know what they're talking about before they knock the upload.  Thanks again.  This is the only method that consistently works.
